text: Her order is clear: go back.

I stand in the snow outside the north gate, my throat tight. She doesn’t raise her voice, doesn’t explain—she just nudges me a step back from the edge of the formation, like pulling out a nail that shouldn’t be here.
I don’t argue. As I turn away, commands ring out behind me one after another, shields crashing together, making even the snow tremble.

The walk back feels longer than the walk here. Streets begin to close off; guards herd people indoors, merchants hurriedly pack up their stalls, and the square is left with only wind and abandoned tables.
Someone whispers her name, then immediately falls silent—as if leaving the sentence unfinished might keep the ending from happening.
I return to the inn, slide the bolt into place, and push a table against the door.
The firelight flickers, the cups are neatly arranged, but the room echoes with emptiness—like it’s missing a set of footsteps that should have arrived.
I force myself to move: add wood to the fire, wipe the counter, set my short sword within easy reach. I finish once, then do it again.

Later in the night, sounds drift through the fog from the north: something like a horn—something like stone collapsing. Then comes a long silence, so deep I can hear my own breath scraping in my throat.
I stand behind the counter, my knuckles white. Only then do I realize—I’ve been waiting for the possibility that she would come back.
Footsteps pass outside the door, hurried and uneven. Low voices murmur, as if afraid of disturbing something.
I don’t open the door right away. I press close to it, catching fragments of conversation through the wood:
I slowly loosen my grip on the bolt, then slowly draw my hand back. The room is warm, but a chill creeps up my spine inch by inch.
That night, no one knocks on my door, and no one finishes the story. But the whole town seems to accept one thing: the sun will rise tomorrow—and she will not walk back down this street.
